context: An agricultural science student wanted to test the pH of a sample of soil before deciding what crops to sow.

parts.text: Identify any two pieces of equipment labelled A, B or C required for this investigation.
State the pH of the soil filtrate.
State a conclusion the student can make in relation to growing crops.

Four out of every five calves born on beef farms are sired by a stock bull. The stock bull fertility is key to maintaining a compact calving period, increasing the genetic merit and value of the calves, and overall herd profitability.

subparts.text:
Explain the underlined terms.
Compact calving period:
Increasing genetic merit:

parts.text:
The vet was called to a farm to carry out a fertility test on four stock bulls. The vet collected a sample of semen from the four bulls for analysis. The results are shown in the table below.
Analyse the table and the questions which follow.
Bull 1 Bull 2 Bull 3 Bull 4
Sperm motility (%) 100 95 90 95
Abnormal structure (%) 5 8 8 10

subparts.text: Identify which bull has the most abnormal sperm cells.
Identify which bull has the best sperm motility.
State which bull is the most fertile and best to use with the maiden heifers on the farm.

parts.text: Draw a labelled diagram showing this activity.

context:
Read the article and the questions which follow.
Using a Portable Microscope in Agriculture
You sow seeds, water them and collect the harvest. Crop production involves continuous monitoring and inspection.
Crop plants respond to environmental changes and many internal factors. Plants are also prone to many diseases caused by organisms. Some of these diseases are contagious. Farmers often need to send away diseased crop samples for further analysis including microscopic analysis. The development of portable microscope technology will allow for on-site testing.
(Adapted from Medprimetech, 2022)

parts.text: List two examples of environmental factors that can affect crop production.
Briefly explain how this new onsite technology can benefit crop production.

(i) Pat is doing a screening on his dairy herd. He wanted to check the quality of a milk sample. Describe with the aid of a labelled diagram, how he would carry out this investigation. Labelled diagram: (ii) Identify the following variables in the investigation in part (i). Independent Dependent Control (iii) State with reason if the data collected is qualitative or quantitative.

(i) Based on the results of his investigation, he noticed that the total bacterial count (TBC) had increased. Outline ways Pat could reduce the number of bacteria entering the milk. (ii) Pat gets paid for the milk produced based on its quality using the calculation A + B – C. Calculate the price Pat gets for 1000 litres of his milk in the table below if the milk fat is 3.8% and protein is 3.4%. Milk composition of Milk composition price Price per kg (€) 1000 litres A Fat (€4.48/kg fat) 39.0kg of fat 174.72 B Protein (€9.07/kg protein) 35.0kg of protein 317.45 C Processing cost deduction (€0.04/l) 40.00 Total price / 1000 litres ? Calculation:
(i) Explain the underlined term. (ii) Outline why each of the following ingredients are added to the diet of a dairy cow. Beans Barley

context: A young farmer purchased 20 ewes in his local mart in late November. The farmer doesn’t know exactly how long the ewes are in lamb or if they are barren. The farmer got ultrasound scanning done on the ewes.

parts.text:
(i) Briefly describe the advantages of ultrasound scanning.
(ii) Explain the importance of having a good marking system for the ewes at scanning.
(iii) The results of scanning twenty Number of lambs being ewes are shown in the table. Outline the advice you would give on the management of the ewes, based on the results.

subparts.text: (i) Briefly describe the advantages of ultrasound scanning.
(ii) Explain the importance of having a good marking system for the ewes at scanning.
(iii) The results of scanning twenty Number of lambs being ewes are shown in the table. Outline the advice you would give on the management of the ewes, based on the results.

parts.text:
(i) Advise the farmer as when to house the ewes prior to lambing.
(ii) Suggest reasons for housing the ewes prior to lambing.
(iii) List features of winter housing for sheep.

subparts.text: (i) Advise the farmer as when to house the ewes prior to lambing.
(ii) Suggest reasons for housing the ewes prior to lambing.
(iii) List features of winter housing for sheep.

parts.text:
Describe the management practices carried out on lambs in the first week after birth under the following headings.
Feeding
Housing
Health
